Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: New Frontiers in Reverberation Mapping
Award.AbstractNarration:
In the fifty years since the discovery of quasars, a picture of these enigmatic objects has emerged wherein quasars are supermassive black holes residing at the centers of large galaxies. The black hole may have a mass of millions to billions times that of the sun. As this picture implies, the quasar phenomenon is one and the same as that of the objects referred to as "active galactic nuclei." All are characterized by enormous luminosity such that the quasar frequently outshines the light from all of the billions of stars in its host galaxy. The existence of black holes has captivated people of all levels of scientific sophistication. The study of active galactic nuclei as well as the nucleus of our own galaxy has produced strong evidence that, indeed, supermassive black holes do exist and that they are the engines at the heart of the quasar phenomenon. This project aims to continue the estimate of the mass of the supermassive black holes in a sample of objects and extend it to objects of higher luminosity than those previously studied via a combination of an intense observational program as well as development of new analysis techniques.

This collaborative project will establish the state of the art in reverberation mapping of active galaxies and quasars. Reverberation mapping is a technique where one looks at the reaction of the emission line spectrum of the active object to see how it responds to a change in the intensity of the continuum source that ionizes and excites the surrounding line-emitting gas. It is a technique that has been employed over the last few decades to measure the size and structure of the so-called broad line region in active galactic nuclei, and, in the past five years, the technique has been applied to high-cadence observations to provide the best constraints on the mass of the accreting black hole at the heart of the active object. This project will further advance the technique via a three-phase effort: (1) analysis of data from a high-cadence optical/ultraviolet monitoring campaign for NGC 5548 that will represent the single most intensive reverberation mapping program ever attempted; (2) execution of a one year duration reverberation mapping campaign at Lick Observatory to probe broad-line region structure at luminosities an order of magnitude higher than the luminosities probed by other recent dedicated monitoring programs; and (3) new development of state-of-the-art software for modeling reverberation mapping data. The combination of these projects will make it possible to dissect the structural and dynamical properties of the broad-line region in greater detail than ever before, enabling critical new tests of the local calibration for the quasar black hole mass scale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported research on reverberation mapping of active galactic nuclei (AGN). AGN are supermassive black holes in galaxy centers that are actively accreting matter from their surroundings, and they are among the most luminous sources of radiation in the Universe. Reverberation mapping is a method that uses long-duration observations of AGN and measurements of the time delays between different spectral components of AGN emission to map the inner gaseous environments within just light-days around the black holes, in order to study the gas flows in these compact regions and to measure the masses of the black holes. The goals of this project included carrying out intensive reverberation mapping programs at Lick Observatory and other facilities, and development and application of new methods to analyze and interpret reverberation mapping data in order to determine the masses of supermassive black holes in AGN. Results from research supported by this grant have been published in 28 scientific papers by the UCLA group.

Outcomes of this research include the following.

1) The most intensive reverberation mapping program ever attempted was carried out in 2014 using six months of daily observations with the Hubble Space Telescope and numerous ground-based telescopes. This program led to the highest quality reverberation mapping dataset ever obtained, providing a new level of detail in exploring the behavior of the accretion disk and ionized gas surrounding a supermassive black hole. A surprising outcome is that the broad emission-line region surrounding the black hole in NGC 5548 was found to be approximately 4 times smaller than expected based on prior observations, contradicting previous assumptions about the uniformity of reverberation behavior in AGN. This program was conducted by a large international collaboration of more than 100 astronomers, and a UCSB and UCLA (Treu moved during the grant) graduate students carried out a substantial portion of the data analysis as part of their Ph.D. thesis research.

2) A large reverberation mapping observational program was carried out at Lick Observatory spanning a full year from Spring 2016 to Spring 2017, with 100 nights of observing time allocated to the project at the Lick Shane 3-meter telescope. Reverberation mapping data were obtained for 22 active galaxies, providing new measurements of the masses of the black holes in these galaxies.

3) A new method for analysis and modeling of reverberation mapping data was applied to 15 objects to derive measurements of the central black hole masses and to determine the geometry and kinematics of the ionized gaseous structure around the black holes. The resulting black hole masses are in the range of 3 million to 30 million Solar masses for the objects studied, and the analysis demonstrates that the ionized gas surrounding the black holes is distributed in a roughly face-on thick disk orbiting around the black holes.

4) Several observational programs were carried out to measure the cosmic evolution of the correlation between black hole mass and their host galaxy properties

5) For the first time, a reverberation mapping measurement using 100% robotically-acquired data was published, using robotic telescope observations from Las Cumbres Observatory (LCO) Global Telescope Network, as part of the LCO AGN Reverberation Mapping Key Project. This provides the first demonstration that robotic telescopes can provide the high quality of spectroscopic data needed for such measurements. 

In Treu's group (UCSB->UCLA) this grant provided support for two Ph.D. thesis projects. Additionally, 14 University of California graduate students andpostdoctoral researchers were trained in observational methods and gained observing experience at Lick Observatory as part of this program. Treu provided academic and career mentoring to two California State University undergraduate physics majors through the Cal-Bridge mentoring program.
